Literature Review: The traditional view of perception and memory as distinct cognitive functions supported by separate brain regions has been challenged by a growing body of evidence. This literature review examines the evolving understanding of the roles played by the ventral visual stream (VVS) and medial temporal lobe (MTL) in both perceptual processing and long-term memory. Historically, the VVS, extending from the primary visual cortex to the inferior temporal cortex, has been associated with visual perception and object recognition. Ungerleider and Mishkin's (1982) influential 'two-streams hypothesis' proposed that the VVS (or 'what' pathway) processes object identity, while the dorsal stream processes spatial information. This model has been widely accepted and has shaped research in visual neuroscience for decades. Concurrently, the MTL, including the hippocampus, entorhinal cortex, and perirhinal cortex, has been primarily linked to declarative memory formation and retrieval. This association was largely based on studies of patients with MTL lesions, such as the famous case of H.M., who exhibited severe anterograde amnesia following bilateral MTL resection (Scoville and Milner, 1957). However, recent research has begun to blur the lines between these traditionally separate domains. Several studies have demonstrated that early visual areas, typically associated with perception, also play a role in long-term recognition memory. For instance, Xue et al. (2010) used fMRI to show that activation patterns in the visual cortex during encoding could predict subsequent memory performance, suggesting a role for these areas in memory formation. Conversely, structures within the MTL, particularly the perirhinal cortex, have been implicated in high-level perceptual processing. Murray and Bussey (1999) proposed that the perirhinal cortex is involved in processing complex conjunctions of features, a function critical for both perception and memory. This idea has been supported by numerous studies in both humans and animals. For example, Barense et al. (2007) found that patients with perirhinal cortex damage showed impairments in perceptual discrimination tasks involving complex objects, even in the absence of explicit memory demands. The role of the hippocampus in perception has also been a subject of debate. While traditionally viewed as crucial for episodic memory, recent evidence suggests it may also be involved in certain types of perception. Lee et al. (2012) demonstrated that patients with hippocampal lesions showed deficits in discriminating complex scenes, suggesting a role for the hippocampus in processing spatial configurations. These findings have led to the development of new theoretical frameworks that attempt to reconcile the apparent overlap between perceptual and mnemonic functions. One influential model is the representational-hierarchical account proposed by Bussey and Saksida (2007). This model posits that, rather than a strict division between perception and memory systems, there is a hierarchical organization of representations along the VVS and MTL. Lower levels process simple features, while higher levels integrate these into increasingly complex representations. According to this view, the perirhinal cortex sits at the apex of this hierarchy, representing the most complex conjunctions of features. This explains its involvement in both high-level perception and object memory. The hippocampus, in turn, is proposed to represent even more complex associations, particularly those involving spatial or temporal context. Support for this model comes from various sources. For instance, Cowell et al. (2010) used computational modeling to demonstrate how a hierarchical representational system could account for both perceptual and mnemonic deficits observed following perirhinal cortex damage. Similarly, Graham et al. (2010) reviewed evidence from human neuroimaging and animal lesion studies that aligned with the predictions of the representational-hierarchical model. The implications of this revised understanding are significant. It suggests that the traditional dichotomy between perception and memory systems may be overly simplistic. Instead, these cognitive functions may emerge from the same underlying neural architecture, with differences arising from the complexity and nature of the representations involved rather than from fundamentally distinct processes. This perspective also has practical implications for understanding and treating cognitive disorders. For example, it suggests that deficits in complex object recognition in conditions like semantic dementia may reflect a breakdown in the representational hierarchy rather than a purely mnemonic impairment. In conclusion, the accumulating evidence strongly suggests that the roles of the VVS and MTL in perception and memory are more intertwined than previously thought. The representational-hierarchical model provides a compelling framework for understanding these findings, emphasizing content differences rather than process distinctions. As research in this field continues, it is likely that our understanding of how the brain supports perception and memory will continue to evolve, potentially leading to new insights into cognitive function and dysfunction.
